wikipedia_page.main:
Ernest Rogers Millington  (15 February 1916 – 9 May 2009) was a British Common Wealth and later Labour Member of Parliament (MP).
Following the death of John Profumo on 10 March 2006, Millington was the only living former MP from the 38th Parliament, elected prior to the 1945 general election. He was also the last surviving person to have served as a Common Wealth Party MP.

link_mentions.page: List of MPs elected in the 1945 United Kingdom general election
response: *1946 - Ernest Millington (Chelmsford) joins Labour Party from Common Wealth Party

In April, John Eric Loverseed amounted to the first winning candidate returned to the Commons, by winning Eddisbury. In November 1944, he left the party and joined Labour in May of the next year.F. W. S. Craig, Minor Parties at British Parliamentary Elections In the 1945 general election, voters deserted Common Wealth for Labour – only Chelmsford (not fought by Labour) was held. In 1946 after Wintringham left the party, that MP, Ernest Millington, crossed the floor to join the Labour Party.

link_mentions.page: List of United Kingdom MPs: M
List of UK minor party and independent MPs elected

response: In 1942, Acland broke from the Liberals to found the socialist Common Wealth Party with J. B. Priestley and Tom Wintringham, opposing the coalition between the major parties. During the Second World War, the new party showed signs of a breakthrough, especially in London and Merseyside, winning three by-elections.  However, the 1945 general election was a severe disappointment. Only one Member of Parliament, Ernest Millington, was elected, and other figures left, some joining the Labour Party. Acland himself failed to win Putney, where he came third.
